entry.title: Show HN: NanoClaw – “Clawdbot” in 500 lines of TS with Apple container isolation
entry.content: My personal Claude assistant that runs securely in Apple containers. Lightweight and built to be understood and customized for your own needs. OpenClaw is an impressive project with a great vision. But I can't sleep well running software I don't understand with access to my life. OpenClaw has 52+ modules, 8 config management files, 45+ dependencies, and abstractions for 15 channel ... [summary] [comments]

entry.title: Defeating a 40-year-old copy protection dongle
entry.content: That’s right — this little device is what stood between me and the ability to run an even older piece of software that I recently unearthed during an expedition of software archaeology. For a bit more background, I was recently involved in helping a friend’s accounting firm to move away from using an extremely legacy software package that they had locked themselves into using for the last ... entry.title: Apple I Advertisement (1976)
entry.content: The Apple Computer. A truly complete microcomputer system on a single PC board. Based on the MOS Technology 6502 micro- processor, the Apple also has a built-in video terminal and sockets for 8K bytes of onboard RAM memory. With the addition of a keyboard and video monitor, you'll have an extremely powerful computer system that can be used for anything from developing programs to playing ... [summary] [comments]

entry.title: My thousand dollar iPhone can't do math
entry.content: My iPhone 16 Pro Max produces garbage output when running MLX LLMs. An iPhone 15 Pro runs the same code perfectly. A MacBook Pro also runs the same code perfectly. The tensor outputs on the 16 show numerical values an order of magnitude wrong. I suspect it points to a hardware defect in the Neural Engine or some other ML-needed system. It was a PITA to debug, but at least I got a blog post ... [summary] [comments]

entry.title: Adventure Game Studio: OSS software for creating adventure games
entry.content: Adventure Game Studio (AGS) is open-source software for creating graphical point-and-click adventure games. It is free, standalone, and requires no subscription. The Windows-based IDE, streamlines game creation by integrating tools for importing graphics, writing scripts, and testing. Games created with AGS can be played on multiple platforms, including Linux, iOS, and Android. Rot your brain ... [summary] [comments]

entry.title: Netbird – Open Source Zero Trust Networking
entry.content: NetBird combines a WireGuard®-based overlay network with Zero Trust Network Access, providing a unified open source platform for reliable and secure connectivity "With 55+ sites across UK & Ireland and a growing focus on security, Select Tech Group faced considerable network challenges. NetBird was the answer and made these challenges simple. Posture checks, MFA, SSO, and granular ... [summary] [comments]

entry.title: Efficient String Compression for Modern Database Systems
entry.content: If dealing with strings wasn’t important, why bother thinking about compressing them? Whether you like it or not, “strings are everywhere”1. They are by far the most prominent data type in the real world. In fact, roughly 50% of data is stored as strings. This is largely because strings are flexible and convenient: you can store almost anything as a string. As a result, they’re often used ... [summary] [comments]

entry.title: I taught my neighbor to keep the volume down
entry.content: When I moved to a new apartment with my family, the cable company we were used to wasn't available. We had to settle for Dish Network. I wasn't too happy about making that switch, but something on their website caught my attention. For an additional $5 a month, I could have access to DVR. I switched immediately. This was 2007. DVR was not new, but it wasn't commonly bundled with ... [summary] [comments]

entry.title: Typechecking is undecidable when 'type' is a type (1989) [pdf]
entry.content: Abstract. A function has a dependent type when the type of its result depends upon the value of its argument. The type of all types is the type of every type, including itself. In a typed >.-calculus, these two features synergize in a conceptually clean and uniform way to yield enormous expressive power at very little apparent cost. By reconstructing and analyzing a paradox due to Girard, we ... [summary] [comments]

entry.title: What I learned building an opinionated and minimal coding agent
entry.content: In the past three years, I've been using LLMs for assisted coding. If you read this, you probably went through the same evolution: from copying and pasting code into ChatGPT, to Copilot auto-completions (which never worked for me), to Cursor, and finally the new breed of coding agent harnesses like Claude Code, Codex, Amp, Droid, and opencode that became our daily drivers in 2025. I ... [summary] [comments]

entry.title: MicroPythonOS graphical operating system delivers Android-like user experience
entry.content: Yesterday, I wrote about Ariel OS RTOS for microcontrollers written in Rust, but there’s another interesting open-source operating system for microcontrollers that will be covered at FOSDEM 2026: MicroPythonOS. While Ariel OS is designed for secure, memory-safe, networked IoT applications on microcontrollers, MicroPythonOS targets applications with graphical user interfaces and is heavily ... entry.title: TIL: Apple Broke Time Machine Again on Tahoe
entry.content: Today, after a minor disaster with my Obsidian vault, I decided to restore from Time Machine, and… I realized that it had silently broken across both my Tahoe machines. I use a Synology NAS as Time Machine target, exporting the share over SMB and that has worked flawlessly for years, but this came as a surprise because I could have sworn it was working fine a couple of months ago–but no, it ... entry.title: MRI scans show exercise can make the brain look younger
entry.content: New research suggests that consistent aerobic exercise can help keep your brain biologically younger. Adults who exercised regularly for a year showed brains that appeared nearly a year younger than those who didn’t change their habits. The study focused on midlife, a critical window when prevention may offer long-term benefits. Even small shifts in brain age could add up over decades. ... [summary] [comments]

entry.title: Reliable 25 Gigabit Ethernet via Thunderbolt
entry.content: I stumbled upon this tiny Thunderbolt to 25 Gigabit Ethernet adapter on Amazon. It’s powered from the host, meaning there is only one cable, no additional power supply required. This is great for mobile setups and desktop work alike. The device comes in a nice travel pouch along with a rather short Thunderbolt cable. It is plug-and-play on macOS. You can find the device under many names on ... [summary] [comments]

entry.title: Amiga Unix (Amix)
entry.content: Amiga UNIX (also known as “Amix”) was Commodore's port of AT&T System V Release 4 Unix to the Amiga in 1990. Like many early Unix variants, Amiga Unix never became wildly popular, but it is an interesting sidestep in the history of the Amiga. The two “official” machines that could run Amix were the Amiga 2500UX and 3000UX models, however it can run on any Amiga that meets its hardware ... [summary] [comments]

entry.content: OpenClaw (formerly Moltbot and ClawdBot), the open-source AI personal assistant that can take actions on your behalf, is the most popular topic on X right now. It is already trusted by over 100,000 developers to hold the keys to their digital life, from iMessage/WhatsApp/Slack access to unrestricted local computer control. entry.title: Show HN: ÆTHRA – Writing Music as Code
entry.content: Hi HN I’m building ÆTHRA — a programming language designed specifically for composing music and emotional soundscapes. Instead of focusing on general-purpose programming, ÆTHRA is a pure DSL where code directly represents musical intent: tempo, mood, chords, progression, dynamics, and instruments. The goal is to make music composition feel closer to writing a story or emotion, rather than ... [summary] [comments]

entry.title: Margin Call
entry.content: Last quarter Apple delivered a gross margin of 48.2%. This was above the high end of their guidance range and up 100 basis points sequentially. Management commented that this was “driven by favorable mix and leverage.” Further, products gross margin was 40.7%, up 450 basis points sequentially, driven by favorable mix and leverage. Services gross margin was 76.5%, up 120 basis points ... [summary] [comments]

entry.content: AI agents — systems capable of reasoning, planning, and acting — are becoming a common paradigm for real-world AI applications. entry.title: The Book of PF, 4th edition
entry.content: Peter N.M. Hansteen is a DevOps (formerly sysadmin) consultant and writer based in Bergen, Norway. He also occasionally contributes articles to websites and magazines, and blogs on mainly networking related topics at https://bsdly.blogspot.com/. entry.title: English professors double down on requiring printed copies of readings
entry.content: This academic year, some English professors have increased their preference for physical copies of readings, citing concerns related to artificial intelligence. Many English professors have identified the use of chatbots as harmful to critical thinking and writing. Now, professors who had previously allowed screens in class are tightening technology restrictions. Professor Kim Shirkhani, who ... [summary] [comments]

entry.title: Jack Kerouac's 37 metre-long, first draft scroll of On the Road to be auctioned
entry.content: Jack Kerouac’s original typescript scroll for On the Road – the 37 metre (121ft) long roll of paper on which he typed his defining Beat novel in a three-week burst – will go under the hammer at Christie’s in March, with a sale estimate of £1.8m to £2.9m ($2.5m to $4m). The scroll is one of the centrepieces of the Jim Irsay Collection, one of the most extensive private collections of music, ... [summary] [comments]

entry.title: VisualJJ – Jujutsu in Visual Studio Code
entry.content: Engineers use VisualJJ to stay in flow. It gives you a clear, interactive change tree on top of Jujutsu and Git, so you can see what’s happening, edit history safely, and keep shipping—whether you’re deep into JJ or just tired of wrestling Git. [summary] [comments]

entry.title: List animals until failure
entry.content: You have limited time, but get more time for each animal listed. When the timer runs out, that's game over. No overlapping terms. For example, if you list “bear” and “polar bear”, you get no point (or time bonus) for the latter. But you can still get a point for a second kind of bear. Order doesn't matter. initial time (s): time increment (s): [summary] [comments]
